title: Scott Morrison must turn power into prosperity
text:
Business investment is running at its lowest level since the early 1990s recession, as Mr Frydenberg is acutely aware. But there is hollowness in policymaking. After an apparent reset of relations with business a few weeks ago, the Prime Minister has revealed his populist business bashing streak.

After the “big stick” to break up the energy companies, now it is the overheated language of bank “profiteering” – which emotively conveys exploitation of ScoMo’s little guys.

By not passing on to borrowers all of this week’s cash rate cut, banks are defending their margins in an abnormal, low rate world – and protecting the retiree investors and depositors who helped Mr Morrison to victory.

And here are two sectors – finance and energy – which will be critical if the economy is to return to growth. The election was won by pushing back on irresponsible Labor taxing and spending. Yet this government has been chilling bank lending and killing investment in energy because it too has put populist politics first.

Perhaps that is why it’s no surprise, as political editor Phillip Coorey writes in the Power Issue, that “the signature challenge to Morrison’s power is coming from the business community”.

Nor is it any coincidence that after a decade of leadership madness and policy failure in Canberra from which Mr Morrison emerged, three of the places on the Overt power list have gone to econocrats or business people who would arguably not be there if the government was more on the front foot on the economy.

There is very untraditional tech entrepreneur Mike Cannon-Brookes, who typifies business leaders now filling vacuums that the government does not want to talk about much – in his case energy policy.

Advertisement

Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe has, within a matter of months, become the activist central banker, cutting interest rates for a third time to drive down unemployment and generate more growth. He has been at pains to explain that his monetary levers can do only so much, openly putting pressure on the government to step up more.

And competition regulator Rod Sims of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has shown he is willing to take on market power and reshape industries, including an important world-first inquiry into social media’s impact on independent media and news journalism.

Mr Morrison has begun mending his fences with business. And after a decade of chaos, party politics is now normalising.

It was NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian, a high No 3 on the Overt list, who in March re-established the principle that a government performing well should get returned to office. Ms Berejiklian’s state election win politically validated predecessor Mike Baird’s code-breaking formula for using the proceeds from privatising mature assets such as electricity supply and ports to pay for needed catch-up infrastructure investment in roads and rail. Her come-from-behind win became the template for Mr Morrison in May. Her technocratic leadership style may sometimes lack political nous. But in the end, she stayed in office by delivering on policy.

If Mr Morrison is to use the power as well as win the politics, as did long-lived predecessors like John Howard, then he has to leave the slogans and pick up the policies that will generate growth and protect prosperity.
description: The PM has a grip on his job that eluded his predecessors. But there is a hollowness in policymaking that needs to be filled.
